name: Washington
description: On September 11, 1789, Washington established the first U.S. cabinet, appointing secretaries to advise on national affairs.

name: Washington
description: On July 16, 1790, Washington signed the Residence Act, designating a new capital site along the Potomac River.

name: Washington
description: On December 15, 1791, the Bill of Rights was ratified, adding ten amendments to the Constitution during Washington's presidency.

name: Washington
description: On April 2, 1792, Washington signed the Coinage Act, establishing the U.S. Mint for national currency.

name: Washington
description: On April 22, 1793, Washington declared U.S. neutrality in the French Revolutionary Wars, avoiding European conflict.

name: Washington
description: In October 1794, Washington led troops to suppress the Whiskey Rebellion, affirming federal authority.

name: Washington
description: In 1795, Washington proclaimed the Jay Treaty, improving trade relations with Britain despite controversy.

name: Washington
description: On September 19, 1796, Washington delivered his Farewell Address, warning against political factions and foreign alliances.

name: J. Adams
description: In 1797, Adams navigated the XYZ Affair, exposing French demands for bribes in peace talks.

name: J. Adams
description: In 1798, Adams signed the Alien and Sedition Acts, aiming to protect national security amid French tensions.

name: J. Adams
description: In February 1799, Adams appointed envoys to France, defusing tensions and avoiding war.

name: J. Adams
description: On November 1, 1800, Adams oversaw the move of the federal government to the new capital, Washington, D.C.

name: Jefferson
description: In 1801, Jefferson reduced federal spending, cutting taxes and military budgets to promote simplicity.

name: Jefferson
description: On March 16, 1802, Jefferson established the U.S. Military Academy at West Point for officer training.

name: Jefferson
description: On April 30, 1803, Jefferson secured the Louisiana Purchase, doubling U.S. territory for $15 million.

name: Jefferson
description: On May 14, 1804, Jefferson sent Lewis and Clark to explore the Louisiana Territory, mapping the West.

name: Jefferson
description: On June 4, 1805, Jefferson negotiated peace with Tripoli, ending the First Barbary War.

name: Jefferson
description: On April 18, 1806, Jefferson signed the Non-Importation Act, restricting British goods to pressure trade policies.

name: Jefferson
description: On December 22, 1807, Jefferson enacted the Embargo Act, halting U.S. exports to avoid European wars.

name: Jefferson
description: On January 1, 1808, Jefferson supported the ban on importing enslaved people.

name: Madison
description: In 1809, Madison repealed the Embargo Act, replacing it with the Non-Intercourse Act to ease trade tensions.

name: Madison
description: In 1810, Madison annexed West Florida, claiming it as part of the Louisiana Purchase.

name: Madison
description: In 1811, Madison authorized the charter of the First Bank of the United States to expire, opposing centralized banking.

name: Madison
description: On June 18, 1812, Madison led the U.S. into the War of 1812 against Britain over trade and impressment issues.

name: Madison
description: In 1813, Madison supported the invasion of Canada, though U.S. forces faced setbacks in the war.

name: Madison
description: On August 24, 1814, Madison fled Washington as British troops burned the capital during the War of 1812.

name: Madison
description: On February 17, 1815, Madison celebrated the Treaty of Ghent, ending the War of 1812 with no territorial changes.

name: Madison
description: On April 10, 1816, Madison signed a bill creating the Second Bank of the United States to stabilize the economy.

name: Monroe
description: In 1817, Monroe initiated the First Seminole War, sending troops to pursue Seminoles in Florida.

name: Monroe
description: On October 20, 1818, Monroe negotiated the Anglo-American Convention, setting the U.S.-Canada border at the 49th parallel.

name: Monroe
description: On February 22, 1819, Monroe acquired Florida from Spain via the Adams-Onís Treaty, expanding U.S. territory.

name: Monroe
description: On March 3, 1820, Monroe signed the Missouri Compromise, balancing slave and free states in Congress.

name: Monroe
description: On August 10, 1821, Monroe welcomed Missouri as a slave state, implementing the Missouri Compromise.

name: Monroe
description: In 1822, Monroe recognized new Latin American republics, supporting their independence from Spain.

name: Monroe
description: On December 2, 1823, Monroe issued the Monroe Doctrine, warning Europe against colonizing the Americas.

name: Monroe
description: In 1824, Monroe hosted Lafayette’s U.S. tour, celebrating the Revolutionary War hero’s return.

name: J.Q. Adams
description: In 1825, Adams proposed internal improvements, like roads and canals, to boost national infrastructure.

name: J.Q. Adams
description: In 1826, Adams attended the Panama Congress, fostering diplomatic ties with Latin America.

name: J.Q. Adams
description: In 1827, Adams negotiated a trade treaty with Britain, easing tensions over commerce.

name: J.Q. Adams
description: On May 19, 1828, Adams signed the Tariff of 1828, raising duties but sparking Southern opposition.

name: Jackson
description: In 1829, Jackson introduced the spoils system, rewarding loyal supporters with government jobs.

name: Jackson
description: On May 28, 1830, Jackson signed the Indian Removal Act, authorizing forced relocation of Native tribes.

name: Jackson
description: In 1831, Jackson reorganized the cabinet after the Petticoat Affair strained political alliances.

name: Jackson
description: On July 10, 1832, Jackson vetoed the recharter of the Second Bank of the United States, weakening centralized banking.

name: Jackson
description: On March 2, 1833, Jackson issued the Force Bill, authorizing military action to enforce tariffs in South Carolina.

name: Jackson
description: In 1834, Jackson faced censure by the Senate over his bank veto, escalating political tensions.

name: Jackson
description: In 1835, Jackson paid off the national debt, the only time in U.S. history.

name: Jackson
description: In 1836, Jackson recognized Texas independence, though annexation was delayed until 1845.

name: Van Buren
description: In 1837, Van Buren faced the Panic of 1837, addressing the economic crisis with limited federal action.

name: Van Buren
description: In 1838, Van Buren oversaw the Trail of Tears, enforcing Cherokee removal to Oklahoma.

name: Van Buren
description: In 1839, Van Buren negotiated the Aroostook War truce, avoiding conflict with Britain over Maine’s border.

name: Van Buren
description: On July 4, 1840, Van Buren established the Independent Treasury System to manage federal funds.

name: W.H. Harrison
description: On March 4, 1841, Harrison delivered a lengthy inaugural address, but died of pneumonia on April 4, 1841.

name: Tyler
description: On April 4, 1841, Tyler assumed the presidency after Harrison’s death, establishing the precedent for vice-presidential succession.

name: Tyler
description: On August 9, 1842, Tyler signed the Webster-Ashburton Treaty, resolving U.S.-Canada border disputes.

name: Tyler
description: In 1843, Tyler pursued annexation of Texas, though Congress initially rejected the treaty.

name: Tyler
description: On July 3, 1844, Tyler signed the Treaty of Wanghia with China, opening trade ports and expanding U.S. commerce.

name: Polk
description: On December 29, 1845, Polk annexed Texas, admitting it as a state despite Mexican objections.

name: Polk
description: On June 15, 1846, Polk signed the Oregon Treaty, securing the Pacific Northwest up to the 49th parallel.

name: Polk
description: In 1847, Polk led the Mexican-American War, capturing key territories including California.

name: Polk
description: On February 2, 1848, Polk signed the Treaty of Guadalupe Hidalgo, ending the Mexican-American War with vast land gains.

name: Taylor
description: In 1849, Taylor supported California’s statehood as a free state, intensifying slavery debates.

name: Taylor
description: On July 9, 1850, Taylor died of illness, unable to resolve the Compromise of 1850 debates.

name: Fillmore
description: On September 9, 1850, Fillmore signed the Compromise of 1850, balancing slave and free state interests.

name: Fillmore
description: In 1851, Fillmore enforced the Fugitive Slave Act, sparking Northern resistance.

name: Fillmore
description: In 1852, Fillmore sent Commodore Perry to Japan, initiating trade negotiations.

name: Pierce
description: On December 30, 1853, Pierce supported the Gadsden Purchase, acquiring land from Mexico for a railroad.

name: Pierce
description: On May 30, 1854, Pierce signed the Kansas-Nebraska Act, escalating tensions over slavery’s expansion.

name: Pierce
description: In 1855, Pierce faced Bleeding Kansas violence, struggling to maintain national unity.

name: Pierce
description: In 1856, Pierce recognized the pro-slavery Kansas government, alienating Northern supporters.

name: Buchanan
description: On March 6, 1857, Buchanan endorsed the Dred Scott decision, denying citizenship to enslaved people.

name: Buchanan
description: In 1858, Buchanan negotiated the English Bill, attempting to admit Kansas as a slave state.

name: Buchanan
description: In 1859, Buchanan responded to John Brown’s raid on Harpers Ferry, sending federal troops to suppress the abolitionist uprising.

name: Buchanan
description: In 1860, Buchanan failed to prevent Southern secession after Lincoln’s election.

name: Lincoln
description: On April 15, 1861, Lincoln called for volunteers to suppress the Southern rebellion after Fort Sumter’s fall.

name: Lincoln
description: On September 22, 1862, Lincoln issued the preliminary Emancipation Proclamation, redefining the war’s purpose.

name: Lincoln
description: On November 19, 1863, Lincoln delivered the Gettysburg Address, emphasizing national unity and freedom.

name: Lincoln
description: In 1864, Lincoln supported the 13th Amendment, aiming to abolish slavery permanently.

name: Lincoln
description: On April 14, 1865, Lincoln was assassinated, leaving Reconstruction to his successor, Andrew Johnson.

name: Johnson
description: In 1865, Johnson began Reconstruction, issuing pardons to former Confederates.

name: Johnson
description: On April 9, 1866, Johnson vetoed the Civil Rights Act, but Congress overrode to protect freedmen’s rights.

name: Johnson
description: On March 30, 1867, Johnson purchased Alaska from Russia, expanding U.S. territory.

name: Johnson
description: In 1868, Johnson faced impeachment over Tenure of Office Act violations, narrowly avoiding removal.

name: Grant
description: In 1869, Grant established the Board of Indian Commissioners to reform Native American policy.

name: Grant
description: On March 30, 1870, Grant signed the 15th Amendment, guaranteeing voting rights regardless of race.

name: Grant
description: On April 20, 1871, Grant enforced the Ku Klux Klan Act, suppressing Southern violence against freedmen.

name: Grant
description: On March 1, 1872, Grant created Yellowstone as the first national park, preserving natural heritage.

name: Grant
description: In 1873, Grant faced the Panic of 1873, struggling to stabilize the economy.

name: Grant
description: On April 22, 1874, Grant vetoed the Inflation Bill, maintaining the gold standard.

name: Grant
description: On January 14, 1875, Grant supported the Resumption Act, returning the U.S. to the gold standard.

name: Grant
description: In 1876, Grant attended the Centennial Exposition, celebrating America’s 100th anniversary.

name: Hayes
description: In 1877, Hayes ended Reconstruction, withdrawing federal troops from the South.

name: Hayes
description: In 1878, Hayes was required to sign the Bland-Allison Act into law when his veto was overridden by Congress.

name: Hayes
description: In 1879, Hayes vetoed Chinese immigration restrictions, upholding treaty obligations.

name: Hayes
description: In 1880, Hayes hosted the first White House Easter Egg Roll, starting a tradition.

name: Garfield
description: In 1881, Garfield advocated civil service reform before his assassination on September 19, 1881.

name: Arthur
description: On September 19, 1881, Arthur assumed the presidency, committing to continue Garfield’s reform agenda.

name: Arthur
description: On May 6, 1882, Arthur signed the Chinese Exclusion Act, restricting immigration for a decade.

name: Arthur
description: On January 16, 1883, Arthur signed the Pendleton Act, establishing merit-based civil service hiring.

name: Arthur
description: In 1884, Arthur oversaw the completion of the Washington Monument, a national landmark.

name: Cleveland
description: In 1885, Cleveland vetoed fraudulent pension bills, protecting federal funds from misuse.

name: Cleveland
description: On October 28, 1886, Cleveland dedicated the Statue of Liberty, accepting France’s gift to America.

name: Cleveland
description: On February 4, 1887, Cleveland signed the Interstate Commerce Act, regulating railroads for fair practices.

name: Cleveland
description: In 1888, Cleveland pushed for tariff reduction, though Congress blocked his efforts.

name: B. Harrison
description: In 1889, Harrison signed bills admitting North Dakota, South Dakota, Montana, and Washington as states.

name: B. Harrison
description: On October 1, 1890, Harrison approved the McKinley Tariff, raising duties to protect U.S. industries.

name: B. Harrison
description: In 1891, Harrison created the first U.S. forest reserves, preserving natural resources.

name: B. Harrison
description: On January 1, 1892, Harrison opened Ellis Island, streamlining immigration processing.

name: Cleveland
description: On November 1, 1893, Cleveland repealed the Sherman Silver Purchase Act, stabilizing the gold standard.

name: Cleveland
description: In July 1894, Cleveland sent troops to break the Pullman Strike, restoring rail service.

name: Cleveland
description: In 1895, Cleveland invoked the Monroe Doctrine, mediating a Venezuela-Britain border dispute.

name: Cleveland
description: In 1896, Cleveland maintained neutrality during the Cuban revolt, avoiding intervention.

name: McKinley
description: On July 24, 1897, McKinley signed the Dingley Tariff, raising rates to protect American businesses.

name: McKinley
description: On April 25, 1898, McKinley led the U.S. to victory in the Spanish-American War, gaining territories.

name: McKinley
description: In 1899, McKinley issued the Open Door Policy, promoting equal trade in China.

name: McKinley
description: On March 14, 1900, McKinley signed the Gold Standard Act, fixing U.S. currency to gold.

name: McKinley
description: On September 14, 1901, McKinley was assassinated, leaving Roosevelt to pursue his policies.

name: T. Roosevelt
description: On September 14, 1901, Roosevelt assumed the presidency, promising to continue McKinley’s policies.

name: T. Roosevelt
description: In 1902, Roosevelt mediated the Coal Strike, securing better wages for miners.

name: T. Roosevelt
description: On November 3, 1903, Roosevelt supported Panama’s independence, securing the Panama Canal Zone.

name: T. Roosevelt
description: In 1904, Roosevelt issued the Roosevelt Corollary, asserting U.S. influence in Latin America.

name: T. Roosevelt
description: On September 5, 1905, Roosevelt brokered the Treaty of Portsmouth, ending the Russo-Japanese War.

name: T. Roosevelt
description: On June 30, 1906, Roosevelt signed the Pure Food and Drug Act, protecting consumer health.

name: T. Roosevelt
description: In 1907, Roosevelt sent the Great White Fleet on a world tour, showcasing naval power.

name: T. Roosevelt
description: In 1908, Roosevelt expanded national forests, conserving millions of acres.

name: Taft
description: In 1909, Taft pursued dollar diplomacy, promoting U.S. investments abroad.

name: Taft
description: On June 25, 1910, Taft established the U.S. Postal Savings System, aiding small savers.

name: Taft
description: In 1911, Taft broke up the Standard Oil monopoly, enforcing antitrust laws.

name: Taft
description: On April 9, 1912, Taft signed the bill creating the Children’s Bureau, addressing child welfare issues.

name: Wilson
description: On December 23, 1913, Wilson signed the Federal Reserve Act, creating a central banking system.

name: Wilson
description: On October 15, 1914, Wilson enacted the Clayton Antitrust Act, strengthening anti-monopoly laws.

name: Wilson
description: In 1915, Wilson maintained neutrality as World War I escalated in Europe.

name: Wilson
description: On September 1, 1916, Wilson signed the Keating-Owen Act, restricting child labor.

name: Wilson
description: On April 6, 1917, Wilson led the U.S. into World War I, declaring war on Germany.

name: Wilson
description: On January 8, 1918, Wilson proposed the Fourteen Points, outlining a vision for post-war peace.

name: Wilson
description: In 1919, Wilson championed the League of Nations, though the U.S. didn’t join.

name: Wilson
description: On August 18, 1920, Wilson supported the 19th Amendment, granting women the right to vote.

name: Harding
description: On June 10, 1921, Harding signed the Budget and Accounting Act, modernizing federal budgeting.

name: Harding
description: On September 21, 1922, Harding signed the Fordney-McCumber Tariff, raising duties to protect industries.

name: Harding
description: On August 2, 1923, Harding died, leaving scandals like Teapot Dome to tarnish his legacy.

name: Coolidge
description: On August 2, 1923, Coolidge assumed the presidency, restoring trust after Harding’s scandals.

name: Coolidge
description: On May 26, 1924, Coolidge signed the Immigration Act, limiting arrivals from certain countries.

name: Coolidge
description: On February 28, 1925, Coolidge signed the Federal Corrupt Practices Act, regulating campaign financing.

name: Coolidge
description: On May 20, 1926, Coolidge supported the Air Commerce Act, regulating aviation safety.

name: Coolidge
description: In 1927, Coolidge vetoed farm relief bills, prioritizing limited government.

name: Coolidge
description: On August 27, 1928, Coolidge signed the Kellogg-Briand Pact, aiming to outlaw war.

name: Hoover
description: On October 29, 1929, Hoover faced the stock market crash, initiating the Great Depression.

name: Hoover
description: On June 17, 1930, Hoover signed the Smoot-Hawley Tariff, raising duties but worsening trade.

name: Hoover
description: In June 1931, Hoover proposed the Hoover Moratorium, suspending World War I debt payments to aid global recovery.

name: Hoover
description: On January 22, 1932, Hoover signed the Reconstruction Finance Corporation Act to aid struggling businesses.

name: FDR
description: On March 9, 1933, FDR launched the New Deal, creating jobs through programs like the CCC.

name: FDR
description: On June 6, 1934, FDR signed the Securities Exchange Act, regulating Wall Street.

name: FDR
description: On August 14, 1935, FDR signed the Social Security Act, establishing a safety net for retirees.

name: FDR
description: In 1936, FDR won re-election, expanding New Deal programs to combat the Depression.

name: FDR
description: In 1937, FDR proposed court-packing, attempting to reform the Supreme Court.

name: FDR
description: On June 25, 1938, FDR signed the Fair Labor Standards Act, setting minimum wages and hours.

name: FDR
description: In 1939, FDR maintained neutrality as World War II began in Europe.

name: FDR
description: On September 16, 1940, FDR signed the Selective Service Act, preparing for potential war.

name: FDR
description: On January 6, 1941, FDR delivered the Four Freedoms speech, articulating democratic ideals.

name: FDR
description: On February 19, 1942, FDR authorized Japanese-American internment after Pearl Harbor’s attack.

name: FDR
description: In November 1943, FDR met with Allied leaders at Tehran, planning D-Day’s invasion.

name: FDR
description: On June 22, 1944, FDR signed the GI Bill, aiding veterans with education and housing.

name: FDR
description: On April 12, 1945, FDR died, leaving Truman to conclude World War II.
